author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: The French presidential voting system is simple, but also complex.
description: A candidate who gets an absolute majority of votes in the first round is elected outright, an unlikely outcome that has never come to pass since the French started choosing presidents by direct popular vote in 1965.
content: Presidents in France are elected directly by the people for five-year terms, in a two-round system. This year, the first round was held on April 10, and the second round is being held on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: In a First for the Air Force, a General Is Convicted of Sex Abuse
description: After court-martial, Maj. Gen. William T. Cooley faces up to seven years in prison and dismissal from the Air Force.
content: An Air Force major general was found guilty of forcibly kissing a woman in 2018, in the first court-martial trial and conviction of a general officer in the 75-year history of the military branch, its authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Arab Militia Kills Scores in Sweeping Attack in Sudan’s Darfur
description: The assault by hundreds of Janjaweed fighters, the latest in a series of clashes, was another sign of Sudan's deepening security and political crisis.
content: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Hundreds of Arab militia fighters, many riding motorbikes or driving vehicles mounted with guns, attacked a village in Sudan’s western Darfur region on Sunday, torching homes and shops and killing at least 150 people, aid groups and United Nations officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Some voters in a wealthy Paris suburb consider backing Le Pen.
description: In Neuilly-sur-Seine, an upscale city west of Paris, Marine Le Pen may gain the votes of those who had supported Éric Zemmour.
content: NEUILLY-SUR-SEINE, France — Marine Le Pen has never set her sights on the increasingly affluent Paris region when it comes to rallying voters, preferring instead to focus on poorer areas with a high concentration of working-class voters. But there is one enclave where she may enjoy an unexpectedly high number of votes this Sunday: Neuilly-sur-Seine, an upscale city west of Paris, and one of the country’s wealthiest.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Just Couldn’t See Hanging That Drawing on My Wall’
description: A bit of thrift shop luck, venturing out to a Riverdale bakery and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
title: America’s Road to the Ukraine War
description: For years, the United States sent mixed signals about its interests in the country. Then Vladimir V. Putin made his move.
content: Smoke hung over the gray streets that day in Kyiv, where protesters had piled tires, furniture and barbed wire to barricade themselves from security forces. Torn blue and yellow Ukrainian flags whipped in the wind, and candles left on sidewalks marked where people had been gunned down. A drawing of a reviled president depicted as a pig was tacked to a lamp post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathan Gelgud
title: ‘His Effectiveness Did Not Go Unnoticed’: On the Radical Politics of Walter Rodney
description: An illustrated take on Leo Zeilig’s new biography of the 1960s-70s revolutionary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel and Annie Flanagan
title: ‘It’s Life or Death’: The Mental Health Crisis Among U.S. Teens
description: Depression, self-harm and suicide are rising among American adolescents. For M, a 13-year-old in Minnesota, the despair was almost too much to take.
content: One evening last April, an anxious and free-spirited 13-year-old girl in suburban Minneapolis sprang furious from a chair in the living room and ran from the house — out a sliding door, across the patio, through the backyard and into the woods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Texas National Guard Releases Name of Missing Soldier
description: The Guardsman, Bishop E. Evans, went missing after trying to rescue two migrants in the Rio Grande, officials said.
content: The identity of the National Guard member who went missing on Friday near the Rio Grande has been released by the Texas Military Department. The guardsman, Specialist Bishop E. Evans, 22, is feared to have drowned, though the authorities are still searching for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: A family of six walks for days to escape the besieged city of Mariupol. Here is their story.
description: At times, Russian soldiers were almost friendly, advising them how to avoid shelling and showing them pictures of their own children.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Yevhen Tishchenko stood on the train platform trying to wrestle bulging, woven plastic duffel bags onto an old luggage cart while his wife lifted their disabled youngest child onto a plastic tricycle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Tyson Fury, After Another Knockout Win, Hints at Retirement
description: Fury finished Dillian Whyte with an uppercut in the sixth round and later reasoned he might not need to fight again. Then he teased a potential bout with Francis Ngannou.
content: Half an hour after he dispatched Dillian Whyte with a thunderous right uppercut to retain his World Boxing Council heavyweight title, Tyson Fury sat down shirtless at the post-fight news conference and began discussing his boxing career in the past tense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘We Own This City’ Review: Baltimore Police Problems, Rewired
description: David Simon returns to a familiar beat for HBO, updating if not improving on an old critique.
content: Let us stipulate that it is unfair to compare any series to “The Wire,” even if it is about policing, even if it is set in Baltimore, even if it happens to be made by two of the figures behind that HBO all-time great, which marks its two-decade anniversary this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: This Man Married a Fictional Character. He’d Like You to Hear Him Out.
description: Akihiko Kondo and thousands of others are in devoted fictional relationships, served by a vast industry aimed at satisfying the desires of a fervent fan culture.
content: TOKYO — In almost every way, Akihiko Kondo is an ordinary Japanese man. He’s pleasant and easy to talk to. He has friends and a steady job and wears a suit and tie to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: The U.S. keeps a wary eye on the French elections.
description: United States officials are anxiously watching the French presidential election, aware that the outcome of the vote could scramble President Biden’s relations with Europe and reveal dangerous fissures in Western democracy.
content: United States officials are anxiously watching the French presidential election, aware that the outcome of the vote could scramble President Biden’s relations with Europe and reveal dangerous fissures in Western democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
title: At Least 10 Dead After Tour Boat Sinks in Japan
description: Sixteen people were still missing, more than 24 hours after the sightseeing vessel was lost off the coast of Hokkaido island.
content: TOKYO — At least 10 people who had been on a sightseeing boat that sank off the Japanese island of Hokkaido on Saturday have died, Japan’s coast guard said on Sunday. Sixteen other people were still missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Macron and Le Pen spar in an increasingly divided France.
description: PARIS — In the course of a visit this past week to Saint-Denis, north of Paris, where the poverty rate is about twice the national average, President Emmanuel Macron donned boxing gloves for a moment to spar with a local. “Go on, hit me,” the young man said, “show me what you got!”
content: PARIS — In the course of a visit this past week to Saint-Denis, north of Paris, where the poverty rate is about twice the national average, President Emmanuel Macron donned boxing gloves for a moment to spar with a local. “Go on, hit me,” the young man said, “show me what you got!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech, Abdi Latif Dahir and Oscar Lopez
title: With Us or With Them? In a New Cold War, How About Neither.
description: Old geopolitical foes are facing off after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but much of the world is refusing to take sides.
content: BANGKOK — As the bonds of traditional alliances fray across the globe, the Royal Thai Army, the United States’ oldest treaty partner in Asia, has cast a wide net.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Climate Activist Dies After Setting Himself on Fire at Supreme Court
description: A friend described the actions of Wynn Bruce, of Boulder, Colo., as “a deeply fearless act of compassion to bring attention to climate crisis.”
content: WASHINGTON — A Colorado man who set himself on fire in front of the Supreme Court on Friday in an apparent Earth Day protest against climate change has died, police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Mike Isaac
title: Twitter in Advanced Talks to Sell Itself to Elon Musk
description: The company’s 11-member board was negotiating with Mr. Musk into the morning on Monday over his offer to buy the social networking service and take it private.
content: Twitter is nearing a deal to sell itself to Elon Musk, two people with knowledge of the situation said, a move that would unite the world’s richest man with the influential social networking service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Natalie Kitroeff
title: U.S. Officials Make Top-Secret Visit to Ukraine
description: The American government refused to comment on reports that Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had traveled to Ukraine to meet with its leaders.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Two top American officials, in a trip shrouded in secrecy, made a wartime journey to Kyiv on Sunday, where President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine planned to urge them to provide more aid in his nation’s battle against Russian invaders, a top Ukrainian official said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Ukrainians in Mariupol’s steel mill are holding on, despite intensifying attacks, a commander tells The Times.
description: Capt. Svyatoslav Palamar says he and others would give up the factory if they could leave safely.
content: ZAPORIZHZHIA, Ukraine — Ukrainian forces are still in full control of the Azovstal steel plant in the war-battered port city of Mariupol and have repelled continuous assaults by Russian infantry even while weathering steadily intensifying air and artillery attacks, a commander of one of the Ukrainian units defending the plant said in an interview on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin, Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
title: Inside the Implosion of CNN+
description: Seen as the future of CNN, the streaming channel was suddenly killed. Its soon-to-be owner, Discovery, had concerns but until the deal closed, it was constrained in guiding a competitor.
content: David Zaslav had been chief executive of Warner Bros. Discovery for all of a few hours when he learned he had a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In a Ukrainian School, 12 People Await the War’s End, or Their Own
description: In the basement of a battered school in Kharkiv, a dozen residents have taken shelter. In a neighborhood not far away, life has returned to some sense of normalcy. But they choose to stay.
content: KHARKIV, Ukraine — The shelling had gone on so long and had been so frequent that even moments of quiet brought their own kind of terror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Navalny’ Review: Speaking Truth to Power in a Corrupt System
description: Even with its subject in prison, the documentary plays like a crowd-pleaser.
content: “Navalny” had its premiere at the virtual Sundance Film Festival in January, before Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president, started the war in Ukraine in February, and before the film’s subject, Aleksei A. Navalny, the imprisoned opposition leader, received an additional nine-year sentence in March. The case against him has been seen internationally as a Kremlin effort to lock up a prominent Putin critic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Economic programs were front and center in the campaign.
description: Workers in restless blue-collar bastions may yet prove a liability for Mr. Macron. Despite a robust recovery in France after Covid lockdowns — the economy is now growing at around 7 percent, and unemployment has fallen to a 10-year low of 7.4 percent — many feel inequality has widened, rather than narrowed, as he pledged, in the five years since Mr. Macron took office.
content: After a whirlwind of last-minute campaigning, President Emmanuel Macron and his challenger, Marine Le Pen, faced a runoff on Sunday that  hinged to a large extent on perceptions of the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Ashley Southall
title: Firefighter Is Killed When Ceiling Collapses in Brooklyn House Fire
description: Five other firefighters were injured in the three-alarm fire in Canarsie, the Fire Department said. Authorities were working to identify another body found inside the home.
content: A firefighter was killed after a ceiling gave way in a fire at a home in Brooklyn on Sunday afternoon and another person inside the home was also killed, city officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: In ‘Lucia’ at the Met, a Modern Woman Comes Undone
description: Simon Stone’s new staging of Donizetti’s classic opera updates the work to a present-day American town — hold (some of) the madness.
content: By the looks of it, there is little in common between the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of “Lucia di Lammermoor” and the one it replaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Week in Business: Streaming Hits a Rough Patch
description: Florida takes on the Magic Kingdom. Masks come off on public transportation. And we’ll see how the U.S. economy did in the first three months of the year.
content: After pouring tens of millions of dollars into a nationwide marketing campaign, big-name stars and hundreds of new employees, CNN announced Thursday it was shutting down CNN+, its weeks-old streaming platform. Executives at Discovery, CNN’s new owner, were said to be concerned about underwhelming interest from subscribers. The news fueled questions — particularly after Netflix’s disastrous earnings report last week — about the longer-term outlook for streaming services. Netflix said on Tuesday that it had lost 200,000 subscribers in the first quarter and expected some two million more to leave the platform over the next three months. It was the first time in a decade the company lost subscribers, and its shares plunged 35 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Modi Stresses Growth, Sidestepping Politics, in Visit to Restive Territory
description: The Indian prime minister aims to ease decades of turmoil in Jammu and Kashmir through projects like a solar plant.
content: PALLI, Kashmir — Prime Minister Narendra Modi dedicated a solar plant in the village of Palli in the Indian-controlled portion of Kashmir on Sunday, holding the project up as an example of his government’s plans to convert a disputed, conflict-ridden region into an engine of green development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Farah Eltohamy
title: Wildfires Burn More Than 150,000 Acres in Three States
description: Wildfires in Arizona, Nebraska and New Mexico have left at least one person dead and destroyed hundreds of structures.
content: McKenna Thompson, 30, was not too worried when she learned last week that she was among thousands of people across Arizona, Nebraska and New Mexico who would be forced to leave as wildfires approached.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Daily’ explores what’s at stake in the runoff election.
description: Voters in France are deciding between the same two candidates as the last presidential election: Emmanuel Macron, the president and a polished centrist, and Marine Le Pen, the leader of the far-right National Rally party. But the context this time around is different from that 2017 vote. There is a war in Europe, and the contest is tight. “The Daily” podcast looks at the stakes, and how the race has become so close.
content: Voters in France are deciding between the same two candidates as the last presidential election: Emmanuel Macron, the president and a polished centrist, and Marine Le Pen, the leader of the far-right National Rally party. But the context this time around is different from that 2017 vote. There is a war in Europe, and the contest is tight. “The Daily” podcast looks at the stakes, and how the race has become so close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Mayor Proposes 1,400 Shelter Beds to Move Homeless People Off Streets
description: Eric Adams proposed a $171 million investment in homeless services that would fund outreach efforts and add temporary specialized shelters and drop-in centers.
content: Putting additional funding behind his efforts to move homeless people off New York City streets, Mayor Eric Adams announced on Sunday that he would propose a $171 million investment in homeless services that would include funding for 1,400 specialized shelter beds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Moore
title: Welcome to Sullivan’s, Where Everybody Knows Your Name
description: In “Marrying the Ketchups,” Jennifer Close places a beloved Chicago watering hole in the hands of a big Irish family with lots of politics.
content: A large Irish American family; a large Irish American bar and restaurant owned by said family; said family reeling in the wake of the death of a grandparent; a wayward daughter returning to her birthplace after a failed career in a different city; multiple points of view in alternating chapters as various members of the Irish American family struggle with marriage- and work-related problems: What do all of the items on this list have in common?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cat Woods
title: ‘The Bad Guys’ and the Crossroads Its Author Faced
description: Unable to support his family with his children’s books, Aaron Blabey was ready to give up. Then he came up with the concept that’s now a best seller and an animated movie.
content: The Australian author and illustrator Aaron Blabey gave himself an ultimatum in 2014. The father of two, then 40 years old, had been working a series of increasingly dissatisfying day jobs — from acting to advertising — and although his children’s books were “warmly received” (as he put it), the earnings were not supporting his family. He decided that if he didn’t make a success of them, and quickly, he would pursue a permanent job instead, or as he said in a recent interview, “a life of surrendered dreams, low-level corporate creativity and mundane compromise.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: He Fuels the Right’s Cultural Fires (and Spreads Them to Florida)
description: Christopher Rufo helped make critical race theory a conservative rallying cry. Now he sees L.G.B.T.Q. issues as an even more potent line of attack.
content: GIG HARBOR, Wash. — Christopher Rufo appears on Fox News so often that he converted a room in his Pacific Northwest house to a television studio, complete with professional lighting, an uplink to Fox in New York and an “On Air” light in the hall so his wife and two children don’t barge in during broadcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Demolishing City of the Dead Will Displace a Lively Quarter of Cairo
description: Cairo’s oldest cemetery is being razed, and thousands of families living amid the grand mausoleums face eviction. “You’re not at ease when you’re living. You’re not at ease even when you’re dead.”
content: CAIRO — Whoever was being buried in Cairo’s oldest working cemetery on a recent afternoon had been of some consequence. Glossy S.U.V.s crammed the dusty lanes around an antique mausoleum draped in black and gold; designer sunglasses hid the mourners’ tears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Tripping Through the Universes
description: A new cosmic kung fu film explores the meaning of existence in alternate realities.
content: In 2009, two Stanford physicists, Andrei Linde and Vitaly Vanchurin, wrote a paper calculating the number of possible universes that could exist, based on the prevailing theory, then and today, of how our own cosmos originated 14 billion years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Another Setback for Europe’s Far-Right Populists on Sunday, in Slovenia
description: The country’s prime minister, Janez Jansa, a Trump admirer, appears to have lost to centrist rivals.
content: Europe’s once surging movement of nationalist populists suffered a significant setback in Slovenia on Sunday, in the formerly communist east, on the same day French voters rejected the far-right candidate Marine Le Pen in their presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: The Limits of ‘Lived Experience’
description: Privileging only those voices with a stake in a story carries its own risks.
content: Did Dana Schutz, a white artist, have the right to paint Emmett Till? Was it fair that a white historian, David Blight, won a Pulitzer for his biography of Frederick Douglass? Should Steven Spielberg and Tony Kushner be the ones to update “West Side Story,” a musical conceived by four Jewish men but fundamentally about Puerto Rican lives?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: How to Cultivate Joy Even When It Feels in Short Supply
description: Easter isn’t just one day. It’s a whole season devoted to rejoicing.
content: In the Bible, there’s a question that Paul asks in his letter to the Galatian church that has haunted me for the last couple of years: What has happened to all your joy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: Macron Wins Re-election
description: Plus an announced visit by top U.S. officials to Kyiv, while New Zealand and Japan announce closer diplomatic ties.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France has won a second term, defeating the far-right leader Marine Le Pen in a close competition and becoming the first French president to be re-elected in 20 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: Joyce DiDonato’s ‘Eden’ Takes Root at Carnegie Hall
description: The star mezzo-soprano’s new concert program seeks to restore humanity’s connection to the natural world.
content: It’s hard to imagine what New Yorkers are supposed to do with the seeds of an eastern red cedar tree, given how narrow our window sills are, but they were slipped into the program books of Joyce DiDonato’s concert at Carnegie Hall anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: At City Ballet, Bending the Form’s Rituals and Codes
description: Pam Tanowitz, a deconstructor of the classical, has a new work, “Law of Mosaics,” and a company premiere on the program “Visionary Voices.”
content: “I would rather fail at something interesting than do something boring.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: A mother had found ‘a new level of happiness’ when her daughter was born. Then a missile killed them both.
description: The family had moved from their apartment to a relative’s home to try to escape the Russian attacks.
content: A few weeks before Russia invaded Ukraine, Valerie Glodan, wrote in a post on Instagram that she was living with “a new level of happiness” after she gave birth to her first child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: Vintage Skates and Graffiti Jackets
description: Party looks of the week from the Tribeca Ball, a screening of “Russian Doll” and Flipper’s in Rockefeller Center.
content: Dust off those roller skates. Flipper’s Roller Boogie Palace, a 1970s skating rink from Los Angeles, opened at Rockefeller Center with a party on April 14. Usher and Liberty Ross, whose father opened the original, invited a bevy of famous friends including Mary J. Blige, Dr. Dre and Patti Smith. Not everyone skated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: A Crusade to Challenge the 2020 Election, Blessed by Church Leaders
description: Some evangelical pastors are hosting events dedicated to Trump’s election falsehoods and promoting the cause to their congregations.
content: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. — The 11 a.m. service at Church for All Nations, a large nondenominational evangelical church in Colorado’s second-largest city, began as such services usually do. The congregation of young families and older couples swayed and sang along to live music. Mark Cowart, the church’s senior pastor, delivered an update on a church mission project.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Crouse
title: A 63-Year-Old Runner Changed the Way I Think About Regret
description: Mariko Yugeta’s comeback story shows that regret doesn’t have to drag us down.
content: American culture is saturated with advice on managing regret — which generally amounts to pretending we don’t experience it. The Library of Congress lists some 50 books with “No Regrets” in the title. Hashtags with the same slogan splay across Instagram reels and pastel-painted particle board on Etsy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Nebraska Wildfires Leave One Dead and Three Firefighters Injured
description: Fires have been reported in at least 12 Nebraska counties since Friday, the authorities said.
content: One person was killed and three firefighters were injured as wildfires that began Friday, fueled by high winds and dry grass, burned throughout western and central Nebraska, the authorities said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: For Alabama’s Only Gay Lawmaker, a Political Defeat Was Deeply Personal
description: Neil Rafferty’s painful experience as a young man influenced his efforts to block new restrictions on gay and transgender youth. He came up short.
content: Minutes before Alabama lawmakers were set to vote on a bill criminalizing medical care for young transgender people who are transitioning, State Representative Neil Rafferty took to the floor of the House and pleaded with his colleagues to reconsider.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Fun, Free and Dangerous: Golden State Is Back
description: Jordan Poole’s emergence as a scoring threat has helped give Golden State the flow and feel of its championship teams. “They allow me just to be me,” he said.
content: Early in the 2019-20 season, as the Golden State Warriors were in the initial stages of amassing the worst record in the N.B.A., Coach Steve Kerr tried to offer some perspective. He knew that he had been enjoying a charmed life in the Bay Area. Now, it was time to teach and develop. He had no choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Le Pen’s message found a strong audience in the north.
description: The far-right candidate, Marine Le Pen, has focused on kitchen-table issues, crime and immigration.
content: HARDECOURT-AUX-BOIS, France — Marine Le Pen spent the last two days of her campaign in the deindustrialized, economically struggling areas in the north of France that, along with a Mediterranean stretch in the south, form her strongholds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Orrin Hatch, Seven-Term Senator and a Republican Force, Dies at 88
description: Overcoming poverty and representing Utah, he became a powerful figure in Washington, helping to build a conservative majority on the Supreme Court.
content: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who crusaded for conservative causes and outlasted six presidents in a seven-term Senate career that corresponded to the rise of a right-wing movement in America, died on Saturday in Salt Lake City. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: The Perils of Legalization
description: We answer a common reader question about the opioid crisis and legalizing drugs.
content: Drug overdose deaths in the U.S. reached their highest point ever recorded last year, with more than 100,000 deaths over 12 months. Deaths are up nearly 50 percent since the start of the Covid pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The Nets Need a Miracle. Or Two. Or Three. Or Four.
description: No N.B.A. team has won a playoff series after losing the first three games. That’s the Nets’ challenge now, and Kyrie Irving and Kevin Durant don’t look ready.
content: As an unmistakable feeling of desperation closed in on the Nets, Coach Steve Nash reached toward the deepest recesses of his bench on Saturday and summoned a former star in twilight. Blake Griffin shed his warm-ups, along with some cobwebs, and reported to the scorer’s table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Jim Hartz, NBC Newsman and Former ‘Today’ Co-Host, Dies at 82
description: His role as Barbara Walters’s on-air partner lasted only two years, but viewers knew him for three decades as a correspondent, anchor and TV host.
content: Jim Hartz, the low-key, folksy newsman who hosted the “Today” show with Barbara Walters in the mid-1970s, less than halfway through his three-decade television career, died on April 17 in Fairfax County, Va. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Emmanuel Macron Defeats Marine Le Pen for Second Term as French President
description: The result was a relief to allies in Europe and Washington wary of a far-right challenger who was hostile to the European Union and NATO.
content: PARIS — Emmanuel Macron won a second term as president of France, triumphing on Sunday over Marine Le Pen, his far-right challenger, after a campaign where his promise of stability prevailed over the temptation of an extremist lurch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: For a Series on Mental Health, Subjects Had Questions, Too
description: The journalist behind a new series on adolescent mental health shares the most revelatory behind-the-scenes aspect of the project.
content: Over more than a year of reporting “The Inner Pandemic,” a new, multipart Times project that explores adolescent mental health, I had the opportunity to listen to families and teens share wrenchingly intimate accounts of self-harm, suicide, anxiety and depression. They were helping me do the detective work to understand the experience of a young generation in profound crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Willy Staley, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Marion Lozano and Jeremy McLennan
title: The Sunday Read: ‘How Many Billionaires Are There, Anyway?’
description: Forbes thinks there are 735 of them in America. Another count finds 927. Whatever the answer, the mystery is revealing — and the number is growing rapidly.
content: America is home to 735 billionaires with a collective worth greater than $4.7 trillion, according to Forbes. There were just 424 billionaires in 2012, Forbes found, and only 243 a decade before that. The billionaires keep multiplying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: A victory for Le Pen would be a debacle for the E.U.
description: BRUSSELS — Should Marine Le Pen prove the polls wrong and win the French presidency on Sunday, she would immediately represent a severe danger to both the European Union and NATO.
content: BRUSSELS — Should Marine Le Pen prove the polls wrong and win the French presidency on Sunday, she would immediately represent a severe danger to both the European Union and NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Michael Crowley
title: Blinken and Austin meet in Kyiv with Zelensky.
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III met Sunday with President Volodymyr Zelensky, the first senior U.S. officials known to have visited Ukraine since the invasion.
content: The United States’ top diplomat and top defense official arrived in Kyiv on Sunday, a Ukrainian official said, following other world leaders who have visited the embattled capital over two months of war to signal their support for Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Where Wizards Play With Magic
description: Li Ding’s puzzle will bring you back to the cafeteria.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the constructor Li Ding, who is making his New York Times Crossword debut with this silly, delicious puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: How hated is Macron? The answer could decide the presidency.
description: LE HAVRE, France — No French president has been the object of such intense dislike among significant segments of the population as Emmanuel Macron — the result, experts say, of his image as an elitist out of touch with the ordinary French people whose pensions and work protections he has threatened in his efforts to make the economy more investor-friendly.
content: LE HAVRE, France — No French president has been the object of such intense dislike among significant segments of the population as Emmanuel Macron — the result, experts say, of his image as an elitist out of touch with the ordinary French people whose pensions and work protections he has threatened in his efforts to make the economy more investor-friendly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: Yankees Sweep Behind a Resurgent Outing and an Offensive Outburst
description: After not escaping the second inning last week against Detroit, Gerrit Cole pitched into the seventh and got plenty of run support in a win over Cleveland.
content: Gerrit Cole used a wild weekend in the Bronx to regain his command.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Giants Are Writing Their Own Rules
description: Brandon Belt and Brandon Crawford are the old guard in San Francisco, but they have embraced Manager Gabe Kapler’s new-school approach — even if it irks opponents.
content: The captain of the San Francisco Giants — that’s captain with a capital C, crudely concocted with strips of black tape — reported for duty this season in a boat bearing precious cargo. He wore a white captain’s hat with black-and-orange trim, flung his wares starboard and set ground, at last, on a shimmering emerald green.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘It’s Life or Death’: U.S. Teenagers Face a Mental Health Crisis
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 24, 2022.
content: “Young people are more educated; less likely to get pregnant, use drugs; less likely to die of accident or injury. By many markers, kids are doing fantastic and thriving. But there are these really important trends in anxiety, depression and suicide that stop us in our tracks.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 24, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 24, 2022.
content: An article last Sunday about Beta, a company in Burlington, Vt., that is developing battery-powered aircraft, misstated Blain Newton’s role at the company. He is chief operations officer, not chief finance officer and chief operating officer. The article also overstated what is known about Ver­mont’s use of nuclear power relative to other states. According to the Vermont Department of Public Service, the state’s power consumption is approximately 26 percent nuclear in origin, but state­-by-­state rankings of nuclear power usage are unreliable, and it is not clear whether Vermont had a higher use of nuclear power than any other state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: What We Know About the DeSantis-Disney Rift
description: The Florida governor and state lawmakers revoked the theme park’s special tax status in an ongoing battle that escalated over a recently passed education bill.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and state lawmakers have revoked a 55-year-old arrangement that gave Disney a special tax status and allowed it to essentially self-govern its 25,000-acre Disney World complex. The loss of that designation is the latest development in an ongoing battle between Mr. DeSantis and the state’s largest private employer over a recently passed education bill. How did the rift get to that point? Here is some background.
source.name: The New York Times

title: French elections
description: French election results on April 24, 2022.

author: By Kassie Bracken, Matt Richtel, Ben Laffin and Elliot deBruyn
title: Worried Sick: A Journey Into the Anxious Teenage Mind
description: Why are so many American teenagers feeling anxious, depressed and even suicidal? Our video looks at the science behind the teen mental health crisis.
content: Why are so many American teenagers feeling anxious, depressed and even suicidal? Our video looks at the science behind the teen mental health crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Roasted broccoli pasta, Greek chicken and more recipes.
content: Good morning. I’ll be grilling today, if I can, the first fire of the season where I stay: red oak I’ll let burn down into coals. I’ll make like Pat Martin and get some sugar snap peas over the fire in a grill basket, tossed with olive oil and salt. Hit those with lemon zest and red-pepper flakes when they’re good and charred and crispy, and serve with smoke-roasted chicken (above). Griddled oranges with rosemary for dessert, with vanilla ice cream? I think so, yes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Boss Trump, ‘the Sorest Loser of All Time’
description: Readers reflect on Donald Trump as both a party boss and a sore loser. Also: Reforming the patent system.
content: To the Editor:
